para.inline: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: Will the normal roster for home leave continue to operate in favour of servicemen located outside Australia whilst the Government's plan for demobilization is being carried out?
Is it a fact that men who would not rank high in the points system have been in New Guinea for nearly two years without having been granted home leave?
Will he give an assurance that, now that hostilities have ceased, the leave accruing to these men will >be granted forthwith?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: No. The shipping available at present will be fully taxed to enable the return to Australia for discharge of long service personnel who have been given priority over leave personnel. Movement to Australia solely for the purpose of taking recreation leave has been suspended temporarily. Compassionate and emergency leave will continue to be granted to members in approved cases.

This is possible, although the number of personnel involved would not be large. Neither the area of service nor the time since last leave bear any direct relation to the number of points a member has in the demobilization scheme.
No. See reply to 1. When the shipping is again available every endeavour will 'be made to grant leave to the personnel referred to.

talk.start.para: - On the 6th September, the honorable member for Cook (Mr. Sheehan) asked the following questions : -

quote.para: Is it a fact that numerous requests for newsprint by trade unions and various other suburban district organizations have been rejected? Is there any likelihood of relieving restrictions on the issue of newsprint so that supplies may bo made available to such organizations?

question.para: The Minister for Trade and Customs has supplied the following answers : -

item.para: Yea.

The current annual consumption of newsprint in the production of newspapers in Australia is only, on average, little more than one-half of the tonnage which was used for that purpose in the year preceding the war. This severe rationing is the result of a world shortage of newsprint and the inability of Australia to obtain supplies except on a restricted basis. General relaxations in rationing have been given effect in Australia over the past two years and on occasions when the supply position of newsprint has been regarded as favorable, licences have been granted for the production of ,neW newspapers in cases where only small tonnages of newsprint were involved, and adjustments have been made of anomalies in quota allocations in individual cases of a minor nature. With the withdrawal of a number of ships from the North America-Australia trade in March ot this year, newsprint shipments fell into arrears and as a consequence the policy of granting licences in approved cases for new newspapers to commence publication had to be abandoned for the time being, as the first consideration is to keep existing newspapers in production. Under most favorable shipping conditions it is not expected that the arrears will be overtaken and reserves again built up before the end of this year and in the meantime as the result of the termination oi lend-lease, another factor, namely, dollar exchange has become a paramount consideration. It is possible that because of this factor importations of newsprint will be further restricted and consequently, the day when rationing of newsprint can be lifted will he further delayed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

quote.para: What arrangements have been or will be made for the release of soldiers to take up work in the sugar industry in Queensland?

talk.start.para: - In the period of the last three years prior to this cane season, the Army alone has discharged over 3,000 men for the purpose of sugar requirements. This year, alone, 600 men have been discharged from the Army for the specific purpose of cutting cane, but by the 25th August, 1945, it was reported that only 316 men so released were working on the fields. On receipt of manpower recommendations for full release of soldiers for cane work, the Army will discharge all men recommended regardless of their present location or other war-time restrictions. Men located on the mainland can be discharged quickly, but shipping and other transport difficulties will necessarily delay men located off the mainland. I am taking up with the Minister for Labour and National Service the question of labour for the cane-fields and suggesting to him that the Director-General of Man Power should submit recommendations to the Army for full discharge on occupational grounds of any soldiers required for the cane industry. In the event of such recommendations being received, expeditious treatment will be given by the Army to finalize all the discharges with the proviso, of course, that the release of men now outside the mainland will take some little time. Recently I discussed the matter with Mr. R. Muir, secretary, Queensland Cane Growers Council, and Mr. E. T. S. Pearce, secretary, Australian Sugar Producers Association, who waited on me in Brisbane.
- On the 29th August, a statement was furnished in reply to the following questions, upon notice, asked by the honorable member for Barker (Mr. Archie Cameron) : -

item.para: How many (a) official and (b) semi- official journals or periodicals are published by Commonwealth departments?
What are their names?
How many persons are employed on their preparation?

question.para: The following supplementary information relates to publications issued by the Department of Air : -

subdebateinfo.title: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: WATERFRONT EMPLOYMENT OF PERSONNEL.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Air, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that Royal Australian Air Force personnel were employed recently loading soda ash from the wharf on to wagons at No. 6 Darling Harbour, Sydney?

talk.start.para: - The Postmaster-General has supplied the following answers to the honorable member's questions : -

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Supply and Shipping has supplied the following answers to the honorable member's questions: -

item.para: One complaint only has been received from the Returned Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Imperial League of Australia in Queensland, and in regard to this complaint, the arrangements are that the returned soldier firm in the district will work in conjunction with the firm which was originally selected and which was recommended as being the outstanding firm in the district for the sale of the products in question. In December, 1944, the Commonwealth Disposals Commission issued directions that, where possible, auctioneer firms, the principals of which are returned servicemen, should be appointed. talk.start.para: - On the 15th June. 1945, the honorable member for Calare (Mr. Breen) asked a question relating to the participation of serving soldiers in land settlement schemes for ex-servicemen.

question.para: I now inform the honorable member that the Commonwealth has advised the States that it is in favour of permitting serving members of the Forces to apply for participation in land settlement schemes. Furthermore, it is considered desirable that all relevant particularsregarding the applicant should be recorded and examined prior to his discharge.It will be appreciated that an applicant's eligibility cannot be determined until he is actually discharged ; nor should a final decision be made as to his suitability while he is still serving, since personal interview is considered essential, and this is not in all cases possible.
